header.title: Pagan Christianity?: Exploring the Roots of Our Church Practices (Revised and Updated Edition)

central_thesis: Many contemporary Christian church practices lack biblical support, having instead originated from pagan cultures and human traditions (Constantinian, medieval, Reformation, Revivalist eras). These accretions and subtractions have fundamentally altered the church's character, suppressing Christ's headship and every-member functioning, and hindering genuine spiritual growth. The book advocates for a 'revolution' to return to the authentic, organic, and scripturally rooted practices of the first-century church.

structure_content.summary: Viola's personal quest to document non-biblical church practices, driven by a desire to return the church to its biblical roots. He notes the lack of existing comprehensive historical documentation on the origins of common church practices.

structure_content.chapter_title: Introduction: "What Happened to the Church?" by George Barna
structure_content.summary: Highlights a 'silent revolution of faith' among Christians seeking older, scriptural approaches, leaving institutional forms. Argues that contemporary church practices are often misaligned with biblical principles, stemming from pagan influences or marketing strategies, and emphasizing the need for historical understanding.

structure_content.chapter_title: Have We Really Been Doing It by the Book?
structure_content.summary: Challenges the assumption that current church practices are biblically derived, asserting that most are man-made. Uses the Socratic method to encourage questioning traditions, suggesting that many cherished practices have no New Testament precedent.

Traces the origin of church buildings to Emperor Constantine (AD 327), patterned after Roman basilicas and Greek temples. Argues that the concept of 'sacred space,' steeples, pulpits, and pews derive from paganism and foster clergy-laity division and passive worship.

Details the evolution of the Protestant order of worship from the medieval Catholic Mass, influenced by figures like Gregory the Great, Luther, Zwingli, and Calvin. States that this fixed liturgy, centered on the sermon and led by clergy, represses spontaneity and every-member participation, diverging from the fluid, open meetings of the first-century church.

Contends that the contemporary sermon is an unbiblical practice derived from Greek rhetoric and sophistry, popularized by church fathers like Chrysostom and Augustine. Argues it makes the preacher a performer, discourages congregational participation, and hinders spiritual growth by being an abstract, one-way discourse.

Asserts that the modern pastoral office has no biblical basis. Traces its origins to the single-bishop rule (Ignatius of Antioch), the clergy/laity distinction (Clement of Rome, Tertullian), and hierarchical structures from Greco-Roman culture. Argues this role undermines Christ's headship and harms both the congregation and the pastor.

Explores the origins of 'dressing up' for church (late-18th/mid-19th century) as a middle-class attempt to emulate aristocracy and clerical attire (AD 330) from Roman officials. Argues these practices perpetuate a false sacred/secular dichotomy and social class distinctions, contrasting with the early church's simplicity.

Examines the development of choirs and worship teams, tracing them to Roman imperial ceremonies and Greek pagan worship in the fourth century, with instruments introduced later in the Middle Ages. Argues professional music leaders limit every-member participation and foster a spectator dynamic, unlike the spontaneous, corporate singing of the early church.

Argues that tithing is an ancient Israelite taxation system, not a New Testament command for Christians. States clergy salaries were instituted by Constantine in the fourth century. These practices, it is argued, burden the poor, create passive dependence on paid professionals, and lack biblical justification for the New Covenant.

Contends that water baptism and the Lord's Supper have been diluted from their original first-century practice. Baptism became separated from conversion and ritualized, while the Lord's Supper transformed from a festive communal meal into a somber, symbolic ritual officiated by clergy, influenced by pagan mystery religions and transubstantiation.

Traces the origins of seminaries, Bible colleges, and Sunday schools to post-apostolic times, noting their foundation in Greek philosophy (Plato, Aristotle) and scholastic theology. Criticizes this intellectual, abstract approach for failing to provide practical, experiential, and spiritual training for ministry, contrasting it with the 'on-the-job' apprenticeship of the early church.

Critiques the common 'proof-texting' method of biblical study, which fragments Scripture and distorts its historical context. Advocates for understanding the New Testament panoramically and chronologically, arguing this approach reveals the consistent spiritual principles for organic church life that are missed by decontextualized reading.

structure_content.chapter_title: A Second Glance at the Savior: Jesus, the Revolutionary
structure_content.summary: Presents Jesus as a 'revolutionary' who challenged religious traditions and the establishment, arguing that exposing and correcting unbiblical church practices today is an expression of His revolutionary nature. Calls for Christians to embrace Christ's original design for His body.

key_concepts.definition: The central question posed by the book, implying that many contemporary Christian practices have roots in ancient pagan traditions rather than biblical mandates.

A church model advocated by the authors, characterized by being born out of spiritual life, Spirit-led, featuring open-participatory meetings, nonhierarchical leadership, every-member functioning, and the centrality of Christ's headship, in contrast to human-constructed institutional churches.

The dominant model of contemporary Christianity, structured by human institutions, religious programs, and clergy-led practices, which the book critiques as being rooted in tradition and pagan influences rather than New Testament principles.

A Greek word for 'church' used in the New Testament, consistently referring to an 'assembly of people' rather than a physical building or a religious service, a distinction central to the book's critique.

The belief that certain individuals (priests, clergy) are divinely appointed mediators between God and people, possessing special powers or status. The book argues this concept is unbiblical and derived from pagan and Old Testament traditions.

A method of biblical study wherein isolated, decontextualized verses of Scripture are used to 'prove' a particular doctrine or practice, often leading to misapplication and a fragmented understanding of the Bible. This method is criticized as fostering man-made traditions.

An unbiblical distinction between 'professional' (clergy) and 'nonprofessional' (laity) Christians, which the book argues perpetuates the false idea that some Christians are more privileged to serve God, hindering every-member functioning.

The one-bishop rule, a hierarchical leadership structure where a single bishop is elevated above other elders, a model that emerged in the early church due to figures like Ignatius of Antioch and became a precursor to the modern pastoral office.

A raised platform in a church from which sermons are delivered. It symbolizes the centrality of preaching in Protestant worship and the elevated status of the clergy, derived from Greek rhetorical traditions rather than early Christian practice.

A pointed structure atop a church building, traced to ancient Babylonian, Egyptian, and Gothic architecture. It is seen as a symbol of man's aspiration to unite with the Creator, contributing to an awe-inspiring, transcendent atmosphere, and contradicting the New Testament message of God's accessibility.

A practice, popularized by Charles Finney and Methodists, of inviting individuals to come forward during a service to receive prayer or commit to Christ. The book argues this is a human invention driven by pragmatism, not a biblical practice.

A model of prayer for conversion, originated by D. L. Moody and popularized by Billy Graham. The book states it replaced the biblical role of water baptism as the initial confession of faith and reinforces an individualistic view of Christianity.

A system of training for ministers derived from medieval universities and scholastic theology, heavily influenced by Greek philosophers like Aristotle and Plato. The book critiques this as primarily intellectual and abstract, failing to equip individuals for practical, spirit-led ministry.

A deep, personal knowing of God through spiritual insight, distinct from intellectual understanding or emotional experience. The book emphasizes this as the true gateway to knowing God and essential for Christian training and ministry, contrasting it with philosophical and academic approaches.

practical_system.description: The book critiques established Christian 'religious systems' and advocates for a return to what it describes as the 'organic church' model of the first century. This 'system' is not a fixed magical or occult practice but rather a framework for Christian living and gathering that prioritizes spiritual, communal, and Christ-centered principles over human traditions and hierarchical structures. It aims to unleash the full functioning of the Body of Christ by removing non-biblical impediments.
tools: Critical and prayerful examination of all existing church traditions against New Testament principles and historical origins.
Adopting a 'panoramic' and 'chronological' approach to reading the New Testament to understand its holistic narrative and avoid 'proof-texting' isolated verses.
Reliance on the Holy Spirit's direct leadership and spontaneity in church gatherings, trusting Him to direct every aspect.
Development of itinerant apostolic workers whose role is to plant and equip churches in every-member functioning, then allow them to operate autonomously.
Cultivation of face-to-face, close-knit communities where mutual subjection and Christ-centered relationships serve as safeguards against error and cultism.
Spiritual formation and training for ministry through 'on-the-job' mentoring within the community of believers, emphasizing experiential learning and character development over academic credentials.
rituals: Open-participatory church meetings where all members freely share, minister, and edify one another under Christ's direct headship, without a fixed liturgy or dominant human leader (1 Corinthians 14:26).
Spontaneous, corporate singing of psalms, hymns, and spiritual songs, initiated by any member, rather than led by professional musicians or choirs (Ephesians 5:19; Colossians 3:16).
Living as a shared-life community, where believers genuinely care for one another as family, outside of scheduled meetings, fostering deep, Christ-centered relationships.
Water baptism as the immediate, initial public confession of faith upon conversion, rather than a delayed ritual separated from the saving experience.
The Lord's Supper celebrated as a festive communal meal, emphasizing joy and fellowship among believers, not as a somber, symbolic ritual officiated exclusively by clergy.

Financial giving that is voluntary, cheerful, and based on ability, directed towards the needs of the poor and supporting itinerant apostolic workers, rather than a mandatory tithe or funding clergy salaries and church buildings.
Every-member functioning and ministry, recognizing that all believers are priests and ministers of God, exercising their gifts to build up the body, without a clergy/laity distinction.
Decision-making resting on the shoulders of the entire assembly, guided by the Lord's mind, rather than a top-down hierarchical structure.

relevant_quotes.text: Most contemporary Christians are massively ignorant as to how the church got to where it is today and of how much current church practice is due simply to accumulated tradition, with little or no roots in Scripture. This book provides a useful service in peeling back the layers of tradition, showing the origins of much that we today call 'church.' Christians who want to be biblically faithful, regardless of their particular tradition or church form, can learn and benefit from the book.

This is an important book that demonstrates that many of the practical aspects of contemporary church life, ministry, and structure have little or no biblical basis and are, in fact, inspired by a wide variety of non-Christian patterns and ideas, most of which are inimical to Christian life and growth.

As startling as it may sound, almost everything that is done in our contemporary churches has no basis in the Bible. As pastors preach from their pulpits about being 'biblical' and following the 'pure Word of God,' their words betray them. The truth is that precious little that is observed today in contemporary Christianity maps to anything found in the first-century church.

The phrase personal Savior is yet another recent innovation that grew out of the ethos of nineteenth-century American revivalism. It originated in the mid-1800s to be exact. is But it grew to popular parlance by Charles Fuller (1887-1968). Fuller literally used the phrase thousands of times in his incredibly popular Old Fashioned Revival Hour radio program that aired from 1937 to 1968. His program reached from North America to every spot on the globe. At the time of his death, it was heard on more than 650 radio stations around the Today, the phrase personal Savior is used so pervasively that it seems biblical. But consider the ludicrousness of using it. Have you ever introduced one of your friends by such a designation? 'This is my 'personal friend,' Billy Smith.'

The contemporary pastor is the most unquestioned fixture in twenty-first-century Christianity. Yet not a strand of Scripture supports the existence of this office. Rather, the present-day pastor was born out of the single-bishop rule first spawned by Ignatius and Cyprian. The bishop evolved into the local presbyter. In the Middle Ages, the presbyter grew into the Catholic priest. During the Reformation, he was transformed into the 'preacher,' 'the minister,' and finally 'the pastor'â€”the person upon whom all of Protestantism hangs. To boil it down to one sentence: The Protestant pastor is nothing more than a slightly reformed Catholic priest. (Again, we are speaking of the office and not the individual.)

critical_analysis.relevance: This book serves as a radical critique of mainstream Christian practices, challenging their historical and biblical foundations. It is highly relevant for individuals and communities seeking to re-evaluate their faith practices and pursue a more 'primitive' or 'organic' expression of Christianity. The book's extensive historical documentation provides a robust argument for its claims, prompting significant introspection on the nature and structure of modern church life. Its emphasis on Christ's headship and every-member functioning speaks to a growing desire for authentic, participatory faith experiences.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is Christians, particularly those within Protestant and evangelical traditions, who are disillusioned with institutional church models or seeking deeper spiritual authenticity. It also appeals to church leaders, historians, and theologians interested in the historical development of Christian practices and alternative church structures. The book implicitly targets those who might be called 'seekers' for a more biblically faithful and spiritually vibrant church experience.
